About

Modeling Caulobacter Growth

Jonathan Fox, Eugene Li

Abstract

Growth of a colony of bacteria is modeled as an exponential process in which each division doubles the number of bacteria present. However, the growth model for an individual bacterium may be different from the colony as a whole. In this study, we use data of single bacterium growth from the 2014 PNAS publication from Iyer-Biswas et al. titled “Scaling laws governing stochastic growth and division of single bacterial cells.” In this study, the authors use image tracking and a flow cell culture system to track the change in area of individual Caulobacter crescentus cells as they undergo cell division. In this study, we perform maximum likelihood estimation to evaluate both the linear and exponential growth model of individual bacteria. The median Akaike weight for the linear growth model was found to be 0.8 while the median Akaike weight for the exponential growth model was found to be 0.2. From these results, we show that the linear growth model is a better model for individual bacterial growth.

Summary

We perform maximum likelihood estimation on data of individual bacterial growth. We determine that the linear growth model is a better model of individual bacterial growth.

Acknowledgments

We thank Dr. Justin Bois for his teaching and expertise. We also thank Iyer-Biswas for making their data publicly available.
